elements.name: question3
elements.title: Either way, the customer can make use of her right of return. According to the Swiss Code of Obligations (OR), the customer can return the product within 7 days - regardless of whether it has a defect or not.

elements.name: question2
elements.title: Justification/correction:
elements.correctAnswer: There is no such general right of return in Switzerland. If there is a defect in the product, the customer has a right to a guarantee (Art. 197 OR - Warranty). She can demand that the purchase price be refunded (Art. 205 CO - rescission) or that the defective appliance be exchanged (Art. 206 CO - replacement). If there is no defect in the product, the store may consider goodwill measures.

elements.name: question1
elements.title: If the vacuum cleaner is indeed defective, a repair in accordance with the Swiss Code of Obligations is the preferred solution to fulfill the statutory warranty obligation.

elements.name: question4
elements.title: Justification/correction:
elements.correctAnswer: Swiss law provides the following options for fulfilling the warranty obligation: Cancellation or reduction (Art. 205 OR) and replacement (Art. 206 OR). This does not include repair. If the retailer wishes to offer a repair instead of an exchange (replacement), this must be stipulated in its general terms and conditions.

elements.name: question5
elements.title: If the vacuum cleaner is actually defective and there is no indication of improper use, this is a warranty case, even though the customer has already used the vacuum cleaner.

elements.name: question6
elements.title: Justification/correction:
elements.correctAnswer: The retailer is also liable for invisible defects that only become apparent during use (Art. 197 CO - Warranty), as well as for defects that become apparent later and are reported immediately (Art. 201 CO - Notice of defects). The statutory warranty period for new products is two years (Art. 210 CO - Limitation period).
